awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Adaptation: Targeting Equity in Access to Mentoring (TEAM)
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Adaptation" awards provide support for the adaptation and adoption of evidence-based strategies to academic and non-academic non-profit organizations.

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC) ADVANCE Adaptation project is called the Targeting Equity in Access to Mentoring (TEAM).  The project will promote a culture of effective and equitable mentoring programs. TEAM components include: mobilizing leadership by the Provost, training and support for deans and department chairs, training for faculty mentors, and additional programming including peer mentoring for mentees.  Objectives for the project include: 1) Establish a senior-level faculty administrative position to ensure consistent mentoring implementation and accountability across the University; 2) Empower deans, chairs, and other senior leadership to establish mentoring programs in their departments; 3) Increase and improve senior faculty members' mentoring capacity by providing education and strategies; and 4) Provide cohort-based mentoring to junior and mid-career faculty.

TEAM offers three key interventions that will advance current mentoring practices, drawing on work by the National Center for Faculty Development & Diversity (NCFDD) and the National Mentoring Research Network (NMRN) as well as ADVANCE projects at Oregon State University and Clemson University.  The UNC project will: 1) Integrate intersectionality-informed materials into the NMRN curriculum to address the unique needs of women faculty in STEM fields; 2) Supplement formal, dyadic mentoring relationships with peer networks; and 3) Include the lived experiences and holistic well-being of women faculty in STEM fields as critical, measurable outcomes for faculty success. It is anticipated that the UNC Adaptation project will add to the knowledge base on faculty mentoring particularly mentoring targeting individuals with intersectional identities in the STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The TEAM ADVANCE mission is to catalyze a culture of effective, accessible, and equitable mentoring across the University and across social identities. TEAM ADVANCE addresses 4 objectives: programs for faculty mentees, intersectionality and inequities-informed faculty mentor training, resources/programs for department chairs and deans to improve mentoring across departments, and advocacy and leadership at the provost office level. (Figure 1). TEAM ADVANCE research questions align with these 4 objectives. 

This report outlines progress toward the 4 objectives. Progress metrics include impacts on the 569 unique faculty participants (Figure 2) in TEAM ADVANCE initiatives that were developed and preliminary results from serial Mentoring Climate Surveys administered to all faculty, including respondents who did not participate in TEAM ADVANCE programs (Tables 1 and 2). Finally, this report outlines the institutionalization and efforts that the University is taking to further the infrastructure built by TEAM ADVANCE. 

 Provost-Level Interventions   

A driver for the TEAM ADVANCE focus on faculty mentoring was that despite Provost guidelines created in 2009 for departments to have mentoring plans, consistency in departmental faculty mentoring plans and junior faculty having a senior faculty mentor remained lacking. TEAM ADVANCE invested in a co-PI Special Assistant to the Provost (SAPTA) at 0.5 FTE through Summer 2021. The SAPTA served as liaison between the Provost Office and TEAM ADVANCE. The SAPTA met with 48 department chairs (and other campus leaders) at least once to determine current faculty mentoring, barriers to effective mentoring, and resource needs to improve equitable faculty mentoring. Transition to a new Provost in January 2022 led to increased emphasis on faculty support: creation of a Senior Vice Provost for Faculty Affairs and an Associate Provost for Faculty Development and expansion of the Center for Faculty Excellence (CFE) into a new Office of Faculty Affairs to ensure equitable faculty mentoring and the continuation of the TEAM ADVANCE initiatives as described below. 

 Education for Deans, Chairs, and Senior Leadership 

The SAPTA collected available departmental mentoring plans, confirming continued campus inconsistency. TEAM ADVANCE created resources, intensive workshops, and a workshop series for department chairs on intersectionality and inequities-informed mentoring, faculty mentoring plans, and valuing mentoring and mentors in departmental processes to over 133 campus leaders. TEAM ADVANCE/CFE provided over 15 consultations to departments and schools for new mentoring programs and broadening reach to fixed-term and mid-career faculty. 

Faculty responses to serial Mentoring Climate Surveys from 2019-2022 revealed increases in faculty reporting their department has a mentoring program for junior faculty, mid-career faculty, and fixed-term faculty (Table 1). Improvements in faculty satisfaction with departmental mentoring were noted overall and broken down by gender and race/ethnicity (Table 1). Increases in level of agreement that departmental mentoring programs address issues of gender and racial inequity were noted (Table 1). These findings are trends with statistical analysis in progress. Most of the increased average scores remained below 4.0 (“Agree”), indicating that while improvements are noted, there is need for continued work. The metric that exceeded 4.0 was agreement that the department chair values formal mentoring (Table 1). 

 Faculty Mentor Training 

TEAM ADVANCE adapted the CIMER (Center for Improvement of Mentored Experiences in Research) Entering Mentoring curriculum into a 5-session training series including intersectionality and gender and racial inequities in the academy and at UNC. Over 150 faculty have been trained since Fall 2019. End-of series self-assessment of CIMER mentoring competencies for every cohort average > 4.0 on a 5-point Likert scale. Mentoring Climate survey results suggest improvement in mentee satisfaction with individual mentoring from Fall 2019 (4.07/5) to Spring 2022 (4.44/5) overall and for BIPOC women, white women, and white men (Table 2). 

 Supporting Faculty Mentees 

TEAM ADVANCE created the Women ADVANCE Leadership program (WAL) for mid-career faculty, featuring successful women leaders, leadership competency development, and projects to promote equity for faculty. To date, 97 faculty have completed WAL, and 54 projects proposed, including the successful re-institution of the Chancellor’s Caregiving Working Group to address heightened multigenerational caregiving needs with the COVID pandemic. 

TEAM ADVANCE Peer Mentoring Circles bring groups of early career faculty mentees together with senior faculty mentors, providing peer support and learning on topics like securing mentoring networks, promotion/tenure, work/life balance, and communication/negotiation.  

Mentoring Climate survey results for faculty TEAM ADVANCE participants suggest an increase in confidence in being effective mentees, mentors, and leaders, and in many mentoring competencies (Table 2). Example comment themes relate to community, peer support, safe spaces, and relationships with senior faculty. 

Institutionalization

The new Senior Vice Provost for Faculty Affairs, Associate Provost for Faculty Development and Success, and associated Office of Faculty Affairs provide infrastructure to collect and track faculty affairs data on advancement and mentoring, build community among faculty and faculty development liaisons, expand the campus Center for Faculty Excellence, create new programs for faculty, and, importantly, institutionalize the objectives of Targeting Equity in Access to Mentoring at UNC.
